captions.text:
Yahtzee, do you have dreams? Of course I have
dreams. I dream of the day you stop breaking

into my house to ask me stupid questions.
I dream of finding a commercial grade air

freshener that covers the smell from the basement.
No I mean, do you have Dreams on the PS4,

the new game - well, game-tangent creativity
experience - by the people who made Little

Big Planet who appear to be trying to pull
off the same scam where they get young creatives

to pay to make their content for them. Dreams
is the next logical step from Little Big Planet

in that instead of just making levels for
a slightly twee platformer you can now make

entire slightly twee games from the ground
up with a suite of inbuilt art, animation

and coding tools. I assume people have been
asking me to cover this thing partly because

I&#39;m an established hobbyist game designer
currently doing a side series in which I pledge

to make twelve games in twelve months the
way a small child goes &quot;Hey everyone look

at me&quot; just before they crack themselves in
the eye with a rock. But partly I suspect

because a lot of people started up Dreams,
watched the intro sequence, and then said
&quot;Someone really needs to piss all over this.&quot;

So that&#39;s what I&#39;m going to do, Media Molecule,
I&#39;m going to piss all over your Dreams. And

if you called it that to make me feel bad
about pissing all over it then you obviously

don&#39;t know me very well. The intro and tutorial
dialogue has the tone of a kindergarten teacher

handing out gold stars to everyone for all
being equally special. Welcome to a magical

universe of your very own where you can realise
your wildest imaginings as long as they&#39;re

slightly twee. Bitch, I can realise my wildest
imaginings with a blank wall and a handful

of shit. You didn&#39;t invent creativity. The
invention of creativity occurred in 1988 when

Robert Zemeckis directed Who Framed Roger
Rabbit, and you don&#39;t look much like Robert

Zemeckis. The next step in our creativity
journey is to play the example game, a game

about a broody jazz musician going through
a symbolic odyssey of self-doubt after someone

mildly criticises him which makes me think
he should hang out with Kay from Sea of Solitude

so they can have fun getting the fuck over
themselves together. But because it&#39;s a showcase

it has to contrivedly switch between noir
adventure and cartoon platformer and various

other set pieces and musical numbers which
makes it a bit of a tonal dog&#39;s breakfast.

Especially when the protagonist uses the word
&quot;shit&quot; at one point, which I took special

note of, because it was quite a lurch for
the established family friendly vibe. Don&#39;t

tell me shit&#39;s been downgraded, I hate having
to update my swear matrix. I guess it doesn&#39;t

matter since the sample game&#39;s only purpose
is to say &quot;Hey, we made this in Dreams and

so could you!&quot; Yes, Media Molecule, I suppose
I could, just as soon as I, too, have access

to a studio full of industry standard professionals
and pay them all a salary, but considering

you expect me to release it for free on your
network I might prefer to reserve my cash

for something with a better return of investment,
like heroin. So it&#39;s not exactly inspiring,

it&#39;s like giving someone a bucket and spade
and then lecturing them on the history of

industrialised strip mining. I went through
some tutorials and fair&#39;s fair, it is an extensive

suite of 3D art tools and drag and drop coding
systems that could potentially realise a lot

of complex visions. But the big question that
I keep coming back to is, why bother when

I could just do all this on PC with a mouse
and keyboard rather than having to relearn

basic drag and drop skills with a PS4 controller
like a man clumsily attempting to remove Tinkerbell&#39;s
bra.

Oh Yahtzee you crumbly old gaming insider,
you&#39;ve got it all wrong. Of course it&#39;s not

trying to compete with commercial game creation
tools, it&#39;s a creativity toy for the kiddiwinks

to get their coding feet wet in between naps
and demands for McDonalds. See, I just think

it&#39;s too complex for that. You&#39;re talking
about it being like playing with Lego, I say

it&#39;s more like playing with Lego with a pair
of remote controlled animatronic hands with

a two hundred page operators&#39; manual. Once
these drag and drop engines go past a certain

level of depth I feel like they can&#39;t be that
much easier than just learning to code, as

I struggle to memorise a new language of icons
and seriously chafe Tinkerbell&#39;s nipples trying

to line up a cuboid. I feel like making a
game in Dreams would be like cleaning a bathroom

floor with the eyelashes of a horse - impressive,
yes, but there were much easier ways. And

you&#39;ll have very little use for all that horse-wrangling
expertise you had to learn if you want to

move into cleaning bathroom floors on a professional
level. Even more so after Sony inevitably

decides it can&#39;t be bothered to support clean
bathroom floors anymore and turns the servers

off, sending everyone&#39;s hard work right down
the bathroom drain. Yes, I have completely
lost the fucking thread of this metaphor.

But what of playing the games, what of being
the societal parasite in the objectivist utopia

that is Dreams. The content is arranged like
the layers of a trifle made by dementia patients

- it starts at the top with the cream, mostly
Media Molecule&#39;s example games made, as discussed

above, by professionals being paid money.
Then under that, the custard, the hand-picked

smattering of decently playable games made
by earnest creatives, presumably mostly bedridden

and with nothing else to do all day but count
the ceiling tiles. And then under that comes

everything else, a bottomless ocean of ranch
dressing and polystyrene, mostly games consisting

of two buildings plonked on an empty field
and released as &quot;super early pre-alpha test

demo for the epic open world sandbox action
RPG I&#39;m totally going to make after I break

both my legs and the ceiling tiles lose their
allure.&quot; About fifty percent of which feature

Sonic the Hedgehog. But that&#39;s all to be expected
and no reason to be discouraging. I made sure

to leave a like on the small number of games
that I felt got into the right spirit of things,

offering nice straightforward gameplay loops,
occasionally even original ones, and as I

looked around at the colourful menus and the
careful curation algorithms at work, I found

myself thinking &quot;Y&#39;know, it&#39;ll be a real shame
when this all gets taken over by perverts.&quot;

These things always are, Media Molecule. The
Sonic the Hedgehog fans are the warning sign.

Now Sonic fans aren&#39;t necessarily perverts,
basketball players aren&#39;t necessarily tall

but it fucking helps. Sooner or later they
bring in that one character who&#39;s a bat with

tits and the furries have got a foot in your
door. Remember Second Life? Once a lovely

wholesome attempt at a community-created online
world of pure imagination, now just zebra

dicks and yiff piles as far as the eye can
see. The earnest creators will all return

or graduate to more efficient systems once
the novelty wears off and then all your fancy

3D art tools are so much fantasy penis shaping
equipment. What&#39;re you gonna do, screen all

incoming content for the rest of your fucking
life? Smarter and more dedicated people than

you have tried to hold back the masturbators,
and the masturbators always win, probably

because they&#39;ve got all the stamina. See,
this happy-clappy everyone&#39;s-special approach

just isn&#39;t preparing the kiddiwinks for the
realities of life as a creative. Stress. Rejection

letters. Audience indifference. The frustration
when someone makes twice as much money as

you just from drawing nipples on Princess
Sally Acorn.
